title: 103_s1701
content: The Act is titled the "Social Security Administration Services Preservation Act". The Congress recognizes the importance of public goodwill and accessibility of Social Security Administration offices for all citizens, especially the handicapped and elderly. Discrepancies exist in the procedures for closing offices. The Act aims to protect the public interest in decisions regarding the closure, consolidation, or recategorization of Social Security Administration offices. It also seeks to establish fair procedures for such decisions. The Act amends Title VII of the Social Security Act to address the consolidation, closing, or recategorization of Social Security Administration offices. The Act amends Title VII of the Social Security Act to address the consolidation, closing, or recategorization of Social Security Administration offices. Section 712 defines terms related to public notice and office relocation within the same political subdivision for the Social Security Administration. The Social Security Administration defines terms related to office relocation within the same political subdivision, including the process of recategorizing offices. The Administration must provide public notice at least 90 days before closing, consolidating, or recategorizing an office, inviting written comments on the proposal. The Social Security Administration must provide public notice at least 90 days before closing, consolidating, or recategorizing an office. Factors considered include the community served, availability of public transportation, need for personal service, and impact on employees. The Social Security Administration must consider factors such as community need, impact on employees, and economic savings when making decisions to close offices. The Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner must approve all closures of full-time offices, and a public hearing can be requested. The Social Security Administration must provide a written preliminary determination for closing, consolidating, or recategorizing an office, including findings and considerations. A public hearing must be requested in writing, held no earlier than 60 days after public notice, and conducted on all proposals affecting the office location. The hearing must be held at or near the affected office by an official designated by the regional or central office. Within 30 days after the hearing, a final report must be issued incorporating all testimony and written comments received. After a public hearing, the Social Security Administration will issue a final report specifying the status of the affected office, send copies to the local press and Members of Congress, and provide public notice. Any person affected by the closure, consolidation, or recategorization of an office may appeal to the Commissioner of Social Security within 30 days of public notice. The Commissioner will review the determination based on the record. The closure, consolidation, or recategorization of an office can be appealed to the Commissioner of Social Security within 30 days of public notice. The Commissioner will review the determination for compliance with the law and substantial evidence. No action can be taken during the appeal process or 30 days after a decision is announced. The Social Security Administration must report closed offices in its annual budget submission to Congress. The Social Security Administration must report closed offices in its annual budget submission to Congress, including those closed or scheduled for closure within the past year.
